title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course Overview
This course equips you with research methodologies, tools, and frameworks to excel as a Communication Liaison‚Äîbridging data scientists and creative teams. Over 17 weeks across five phases, you‚Äôll develop skills to navigate data-driven projects while maintaining clear communication with all stakeholders.

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Quick Reference

Course Structure: Five Phases

Phase 1: Orientation ‚Äî Understand your role and set up your workspace
Phase 2: Discovery ‚Äî Learn research methodologies and ask the right questions
Phase 3: The Dictionary ‚Äî Master codebook creation and variable definition
Phase 4: Execution ‚Äî Apply what you‚Äôve learned to real projects
Phase 5: Delivery ‚Äî Present findings and communicate impact



Key Resources

Liaison Obsidian Vault ‚Äî Download on the Resources page
Weekly Journal Template ‚Äî Included in vault; guidance on the Resources page
Data Dictionary Template ‚Äî Included in vault for Week 8‚Äì10 projects



Getting Help

Office hours: Stop by anytime during posted hours or schedule an appointment
Email: Send questions to aleith@siue.edu
Course site: Check the sidebar for Phase-specific materials and guidance

title: Getting Started
text:
Step 1: Download Your Workspace (5 minutes)
Visit the Resources page and download the Liaison_Vault.zip file.
Extract it to a location like: - Mac/Linux: ~/Documents/Liaison_Vault - Windows: C:\Users\YourName\Documents\Liaison_Vault

title: Getting Started
text:
Step 2: Install Obsidian (5 minutes)

Go to obsidian.md and download Obsidian
Install it on your computer
Open Obsidian and select ‚ÄúOpen folder as vault‚Äù
Navigate to your Liaison_Vault folder and open it

First time in Obsidian? - Click the folder icon on the left sidebar to see your vault structure - Open 00_START_HERE.md to read your orientation guide

title: Getting Started
text:
Step 3: Configure Obsidian Settings (3 minutes)
Once your vault is open in Obsidian:

Go to Settings (gear icon, bottom left)
Click Files & Links in the sidebar
Under ‚ÄúDefault location for new attachments‚Äù, select 04_Resources
This ensures all images, PDFs, and media files go to the right place

title: Getting Started
text:
Step 4: Explore Your Vault Structure
Your vault contains:








Folder
Purpose
Action




00_Inbox
Quick notes & ideas
Capture thoughts here first


01_Journal
Weekly reflections
Use the template to reflect each week


02_Literature
Reading notes
Store all your research notes here


03_Project
Active research work
Organize by prospectus, codebook, data, drafts


04_Resources
Media & attachments
Images, PDFs, external files


99_Templates
Reusable templates
Copy these to start assignments

title: Getting Started
section: Step 5: Review the Weekly Journal Template (5 minutes)
text:
Step 5: Review the Weekly Journal Template (5 minutes)
Open 99_Templates ‚Üí Weekly_Journal_Template.md
This template guides you to reflect using one of three thinking paths: - The Connector: How does this apply to my project? - The Troubleshooter: What broke and how did I fix it? - The Critic: Does this hold true in my experience?

title: Getting Started
text:
Step 6: You‚Äôre Ready!
Once you complete these steps, move to Phase 1: Orientation in the sidebar to begin.

title: Getting Started
text:
Troubleshooting
Q: I extracted the ZIP file but Obsidian won‚Äôt open it as a vault - Make sure you‚Äôre opening the folder that contains the .obsidian hidden folder - Try right-clicking the folder and checking ‚ÄúShow hidden files‚Äù if needed
Q: Where do I put my weekly journal entries? - Create a new file in 01_Journal named something like Week_01_MyName.md - Copy the template from 99_Templates/Weekly_Journal_Template.md and fill it out
Q: Can I share my vault with classmates? - Yes! You can email them the ZIP file, or sync it via Git/GitHub for collaborative projects

Questions? Reach out via your course management system or check your course syllabus for contact information.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
Welcome to the SIM Lab. If you are reading this, you likely identify as a ‚Äúcreative.‚Äù You are a writer, a designer, a strategist, or a storyteller. You might feel that ‚Äúresearch‚Äù is the opposite of what you do‚Äîa cold, clinical practice performed by people in lab coats who care more about numbers than people.
This chapter exists to dismantle that belief. Research is not the enemy of creativity; it is the engine of it. At its core, research is simply a specialized, rigorous form of the storytelling you are already passionate about. To be a great researcher, you must first understand the neuroscience of narrative.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
Welcome to the SIM Lab. If you are reading this, you likely identify as a ‚Äúcreative.‚Äù You are a writer, a designer, a strategist, or a storyteller. You might feel that ‚Äúresearch‚Äù is the opposite of what you do‚Äîa cold, clinical practice performed by people in lab coats who care more about numbers than people.
This chapter exists to dismantle that belief. Research is not the enemy of creativity; it is the engine of it. At its core, research is simply a specialized, rigorous form of the storytelling you are already passionate about. To be a great researcher, you must first understand the neuroscience of narrative.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
section: 1.1 Theoretical Foundation: The Brain as a Story Processor
text:
1.1 Theoretical Foundation: The Brain as a Story Processor
We begin not with statistics, but with neuroscience. In The Science of Storytelling, Will Storr argues that the human brain is not a logic processor, but a ‚Äústory processor‚Äù. This fundamental insight transforms how we approach both creative work and scientific inquiry.

The Control-Seeking Brain
The brain‚Äôs primary evolutionary function is to control its environment to ensure survival. To do this, it builds internal models‚Äîhallucinations, essentially‚Äîof the world around us. We walk into a room and our brain instantly predicts:

The physics of the floor beneath our feet
The social dynamics of the people present
The safety of the space we‚Äôre entering
The cultural norms we should follow

When these models work, we feel calm and confident. Our predictions match reality, and we navigate the world smoothly. But when they fail‚Äîwhen the floorboards crack unexpectedly, or a friend acts strangely‚Äîwe feel anxiety. Our internal model has been disrupted.
This moment of disruption is what storytellers call the Inciting Incident. The brain demands an explanation to bridge the gap between what it expected and what happened. It generates a ‚Äústory‚Äù to regain control: ‚ÄúThe floor is old,‚Äù ‚ÄúMy friend is upset about something,‚Äù ‚ÄúI need to be careful here.‚Äù
This is not metaphor‚Äîthis is cognitive architecture. The brain is literally constructing narrative explanations to maintain its sense of control over reality.


The Narrative Imperative
Consider this example: You‚Äôre scrolling through social media and notice that three different friends have posted about the same new app within 24 hours. Your brain immediately constructs explanatory narratives:

Story 1: ‚ÄúThis app must be going viral.‚Äù
Story 2: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs probably an influencer campaign happening.‚Äù
Story 3: ‚ÄúMaybe there‚Äôs a new feature that solves a common problem.‚Äù

You haven‚Äôt analyzed data. You haven‚Äôt run statistics. Yet your brain has already generated three competing hypotheses to explain the pattern you observed. This is the storytelling mechanism at work‚Äîand it‚Äôs the foundation of scientific thinking.
The difference between casual observation and research is simply this: Research subjects these narrative explanations to systematic testing.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
1.2 Research as Plot
Scientific inquiry follows the exact same structure as a compelling novel. We can map the components of a standard research study directly onto the components of a narrative arc:

The Story Structure of Science

1. The Inciting Incident ‚Üí The Research Problem
The story begins with a gap in knowledge. You observe an anomaly in the media landscape that violates your expectations:

‚ÄúWhy is everyone suddenly watching chess on Twitch?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy did that Super Bowl ad go viral when others didn‚Äôt?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy are teen girls abandoning Instagram for BeReal?‚Äù

This violation of your expectations drives the plot forward. In academic writing, we call this the research problem or research question. In screenwriting, it‚Äôs the moment the protagonist‚Äôs normal world shatters.
Example: In March 2020, we noticed people flooding onto Twitch‚Äînot to watch esports professionals, but just to ‚Äúhang out‚Äù in low-stakes streams. This didn‚Äôt match our model of Twitch as a gaming platform. That gap became our research question.


2. The Protagonist ‚Üí The Researcher
This is you. You are the detective entering the unknown world to find the truth. Like any protagonist, you bring:

Skills: Your training in theory, methods, and critical thinking
Tools: Your research instruments (surveys, scrapers, interviews)
Motivation: Curiosity, career goals, or a desire to solve a real-world problem
Constraints: Time, budget, ethical boundaries

Your journey through the research process will change you. By the end, you‚Äôll know something you didn‚Äôt know before‚Äîand that transformation is what makes you the protagonist.


3. The Antagonist ‚Üí The Data
In research, the antagonist is not a villain, but chaos. It is:

The overwhelming noise of unorganized information
The difficulty of accessing data
The complexity of human behavior
The statistical variation that obscures patterns
The ethical and logistical barriers to perfect knowledge

Your goal is to defeat this chaos by organizing it. You impose structure on the formless through:

Coding schemes that categorize messy text
Variables that quantify complex phenomena
Statistical tests that separate signal from noise
Visualizations that reveal hidden patterns

The antagonist resists. Your sample is biased. Your coding is inconsistent. Your results are inconclusive. The plot thickens.


4. The Rising Action ‚Üí Data Collection
Like any good story, research builds tension. You:

Design your study (plotting your path into the unknown)
Gain IRB approval (crossing the threshold)
Collect your data (venturing into the dark forest)
Encounter obstacles (participant dropout, API changes, messy data)

Each setback increases the stakes. Will you find the answer? Will the data support your hypothesis? The reader (or reviewer) leans forward.


5. The Climax ‚Üí The Analysis
This is the moment of truth. You run your statistical test or finalize your coding. The tension breaks, and the answer is revealed:

‚Äúp < .05‚Äù ‚Äî The relationship is significant!
‚ÄúKappa = .82‚Äù ‚Äî The coding is reliable!
‚Äúr = .67‚Äù ‚Äî The correlation is strong!

Or perhaps:

‚Äúp = .43‚Äù ‚Äî No significant relationship found.
‚ÄúThe data was too noisy to draw conclusions.‚Äù

Even null findings tell a story. They tell us that the world is more complex than we thought‚Äîthat our initial model needs refinement.


6. The Resolution ‚Üí The Discussion
Like any story‚Äôs resolution, the Discussion section answers: ‚ÄúWhat does this mean?‚Äù

How does this finding change our understanding?
What are the implications for practitioners?
What should we study next?
How do we update our model of the world?

The protagonist (you) has transformed. You entered with a question; you exit with an answer (or a more sophisticated question).



Example: Mapping a Real Study
Let‚Äôs apply this to the Twitch study:








Story Element
Research Element
Our Example




Inciting Incident
Research Problem
People suddenly flocking to Twitch during quarantine


Protagonist
Researcher
SIM Lab team investigating streaming behavior


Antagonist
Data Chaos
Millions of chat messages, multiple languages, spam


Rising Action
Data Collection
Scraping 50,000+ chat logs from 200+ streams


Climax
Analysis
Statistical tests showing increased social/tension-release language


Resolution
Discussion
Twitch served as digital ‚Äúthird place‚Äù during isolation

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
section: 1.3 The Sacred Flaw: The Null Hypothesis
text:
1.3 The Sacred Flaw: The Null Hypothesis
Perhaps the most powerful concept Storr offers is the ‚ÄúSacred Flaw.‚Äù In fiction, a protagonist often clings to an erroneous belief about the world that protects their identity:

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need anyone‚Äù (Elsa in Frozen)
‚ÄúMoney equals happiness‚Äù (Charles Foster Kane in Citizen Kane)
‚ÄúThe past defines me‚Äù (Simba in The Lion King)

The plot forces them to confront this flaw. By the climax, they must abandon their false belief to achieve their goal.

The Null Hypothesis as Sacred Flaw
In science, we have a name for this Sacred Flaw: the Null Hypothesis (H‚ÇÄ).
The Null Hypothesis is the assumption that the world is boring and static‚Äîthat there is no relationship between variables, no effect, and no change. It is the ‚Äúflawed‚Äù model we currently accept as true until proven otherwise.
Examples:







Sacred Flaw (H‚ÇÄ)
The Story (H‚ÇÅ)




Violent video games have no effect on children
Actually, the data suggests they desensitize players to aggression


Social media usage is unrelated to anxiety
Actually, heavy use correlates with increased anxiety symptoms


Brand logos don‚Äôt influence purchasing
Actually, exposure to luxury logos triggers status-seeking behavior


Streaming is just entertainment
Actually, it serves social integration functions during isolation



Scientific inquiry is the process of exposing the Sacred Flaws in our collective understanding of media. We assume the current model (H‚ÇÄ) is true until the data becomes so overwhelming that we are forced to rewrite the story.


The Burden of Proof
Just as a fictional protagonist must earn their transformation through struggle, we cannot simply declare the Sacred Flaw false. We must:

State the null clearly: ‚ÄúThere is no relationship between X and Y‚Äù
Collect rigorous evidence: Through valid, reliable methods
Test statistically: Is the pattern we see just random chance?
Reach a threshold: Typically p < .05 (less than 5% chance of randomness)
Only then reject H‚ÇÄ: And accept that the world is different than we thought

This is storytelling with stakes. We‚Äôre not just entertaining readers‚Äîwe‚Äôre revising humanity‚Äôs collective understanding of reality.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
1.4 Connecting Journalism to Data Science
If you can think like a journalist, you can act like a data scientist. Both professions share a single goal: to uncover the truth about the world. The difference lies only in the scale of the evidence.

The Journalist‚Äôs Toolkit
A journalist investigates a story by:

Observing: Noticing patterns in the world (e.g., ‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs talking about this new app‚Äù)
Interviewing: Gathering firsthand accounts (e.g., ‚ÄúI spoke to 10 users who‚Ä¶‚Äù)
Contextualizing: Providing historical and cultural background
Synthesizing: Weaving observations into a coherent narrative

The journalist‚Äôs strength is depth. They can capture the texture of human experience‚Äîthe fear in someone‚Äôs voice, the cultural nuance of a trend, the emotional weight of a moment.


The Data Scientist‚Äôs Toolkit
A data scientist investigates the same story by:

Observing: Noticing patterns in data (e.g., ‚ÄúApp downloads increased 300%‚Äù)
Measuring: Gathering systematic evidence (e.g., ‚ÄúWe tracked 10,000 users over 6 months‚Äù)
Modeling: Testing theoretical explanations statistically
Generalizing: Identifying patterns that apply beyond individual cases

The data scientist‚Äôs strength is breadth. They can detect patterns invisible to individual observation‚Äîthe aggregate behavior of millions, the statistical correlation hidden in noise.


The Liaison‚Äôs Integration
You are learning to be both. You will:

Start with journalistic curiosity (What‚Äôs happening? Why does it matter?)
Gather systematic evidence (Let‚Äôs measure this at scale)
Analyze with statistical rigor (Is this pattern real or random?)
Communicate with narrative clarity (Here‚Äôs what this means for real people)

This is the power of the Communication Liaison: You speak both languages.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
section: 1.5 Case Study: Twitch in the Time of Quarantine
text:
1.5 Case Study: Twitch in the Time of Quarantine
To illustrate this evolution from journalist to data scientist, let‚Äôs examine a study conducted at the SIM Lab: ‚ÄúTwitch in the Time of Quarantine‚Äù (Leith & Gheen, 2022).

Phase 1: The Journalist‚Äôs Observation
March 2020: As the COVID-19 lockdowns began, we noticed a massive cultural shift. Everyone we knew was suddenly logging onto Twitch‚Äînot just for gaming, but just to ‚Äúhang out.‚Äù Streams with low production value and no competitive gameplay were getting thousands of viewers.
A journalist might write a think-piece titled: ‚ÄúHow We Are Coping Online: The Rise of Parasocial Comfort in Digital Spaces.‚Äù
This is a valid observation. It‚Äôs culturally insightful. But it‚Äôs anecdotal‚Äîbased on personal experience and limited interviews. A skeptical editor might ask:

‚ÄúHow do you know this is widespread?‚Äù
‚ÄúCould you just be noticing it because you‚Äôre online more?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the evidence beyond your friend group?‚Äù



Phase 2: The Scientist‚Äôs Inquiry
We took that observation and subjected it to the ‚ÄúScientific Plot.‚Äù

The Inciting Incident (Research Problem)
Why are people flocking to a gaming site during a health crisis‚Äîespecially people who aren‚Äôt gamers?


The Theory (Our Lens)
We applied Uses and Gratifications Theory (Katz, Blumler, & Gurevitch, 1974), which argues people use media to satisfy specific psychological needs:

Social Integrative needs: The need to belong, to feel connected
Tension Release needs: The need to escape, to relax

Our hypothesis: During quarantine, when in-person socializing became impossible, people turned to Twitch to satisfy these needs at scale.


The Investigation (Data Collection)
We scraped thousands of chat logs from Twitch streams spanning two time periods:

Pre-Pandemic: January‚ÄìFebruary 2020
During Pandemic: March‚ÄìMay 2020

We collected: - Chat volume (messages per minute) - Emotional sentiment (positive, negative, neutral) - Social language (greetings, gratitude, community references) - Content focus (game-related vs.¬†off-topic conversation)


The Analysis (The Climax)
Using computational text analysis and statistical testing, we found:

Chat volume increased 47% during the pandemic
Social integrative language increased 31% (e.g., ‚Äúmiss you guys,‚Äù ‚Äúfeels good to be here‚Äù)
Tension-release expressions increased 28% (e.g., ‚Äúneed this right now,‚Äù ‚Äúescaping reality‚Äù)
Off-topic conversation increased 19% (people talking about quarantine life, not games)

Statistical tests confirmed these increases were significant (p < .001), meaning there was less than a 0.1% chance they occurred randomly.


The Resolution (Discussion)
We moved from ‚Äúvibes‚Äù (people seem lonely) to ‚Äúvariables‚Äù (a statistically significant rise in social integrative messaging).
Our conclusion: During COVID-19 lockdowns, Twitch functioned as a digital third place‚Äîa public space where people gathered not to consume content, but to simply be together in a shared experience.



What Changed?







Journalistic Approach
Scientific Approach




‚ÄúPeople seem to be using Twitch differently‚Äù
‚ÄúChat volume increased 47% (p < .001)‚Äù


‚ÄúIt feels like a coping mechanism‚Äù
‚ÄúTension-release language up 28%‚Äù


‚ÄúBased on my observations‚Äù
‚ÄúBased on analysis of 50,000+ messages‚Äù


‚ÄúThis matters to me and my community‚Äù
‚ÄúThis generalizes to millions of users‚Äù



Both approaches are valuable. The journalist provides the soul (the human story). The scientist provides the spine (the empirical evidence).

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
1.6 Anecdote vs.¬†Data: The Creative Tension
The ‚ÄúJournalist‚Äù in you collects anecdotes: specific, emotional stories about individuals.
Example: Interviewing one Twitch streamer about their anxiety during quarantine, hearing them describe crying during a stream when chat showed overwhelming support.
The ‚ÄúScientist‚Äù in you collects data: the aggregation of thousands of anecdotes to prove a pattern.
Example: Counting how many streamers‚Äô chats contained supportive language, correlating it with viewership retention, and testing whether this pattern held across different stream categories.

Neither Is Sufficient Alone
A white paper with only data is dry:

‚ÄúOur analysis of 50,000 chat messages revealed a 31% increase in social integrative language (M = 4.2, SD = 1.7) compared to baseline (M = 3.2, SD = 1.4), t(498) = 7.84, p < .001.‚Äù

This is rigorous, but soulless. The reader‚Äôs eyes glaze over.
A white paper with only anecdotes is unproven:

‚ÄúI spoke to Sarah, a streamer who told me she felt more connected to her audience during quarantine. She said, ‚ÄòIt was like we were all going through this together.‚Äô This shows how Twitch became a space for community during isolation.‚Äù

This is compelling, but unscientific. The reader wonders: ‚ÄúBut is Sarah‚Äôs experience typical? Or just one person‚Äôs story?‚Äù


The Liaison‚Äôs Synthesis
The Publisher (you, by Week 17) uses both:

‚ÄúDuring the COVID-19 lockdowns, Twitch emerged as a digital refuge. Sarah, a variety streamer from Ohio, described the shift: ‚ÄòIt was like we were all going through this together.‚Äô Our analysis of 50,000 chat messages confirms Sarah‚Äôs intuition was widespread‚Äîsocial integrative language increased 31% during quarantine (p < .001), suggesting millions of users turned to Twitch not just for entertainment, but for human connection.‚Äù

This synthesis: - Opens with context (the pandemic) - Introduces a human face (Sarah) - Uses her words (emotional resonance) - Validates with data (statistical evidence) - Explains significance (millions of users)
This is the power of combining journalism and data science. You‚Äôre not just reporting facts‚Äîyou‚Äôre telling the truth in a way that moves people and withstands scrutiny.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
section: 1.7 The Research Mindset: From Consumer to Creator
text:
1.7 The Research Mindset: From Consumer to Creator
Most of your life, you‚Äôve been a consumer of research: reading studies, citing sources, trusting experts. In this course, you become a creator of research: generating knowledge, testing theories, adding to the scholarly conversation.
This shift requires three mental transformations:

1. From Certainty to Curiosity
Old Mindset: ‚ÄúThe answer is in the textbook. I just need to find it.‚Äù
New Mindset: ‚ÄúThe answer doesn‚Äôt exist yet. I need to create it.‚Äù
Research is not about memorizing facts‚Äîit‚Äôs about generating new facts. You must become comfortable with uncertainty, ambiguity, and the possibility that your hypothesis is wrong.


2. From Description to Explanation
Old Mindset: ‚ÄúThis is what happened.‚Äù (Reporting)
New Mindset: ‚ÄúThis is why it happened.‚Äù (Analysis)
Description tells us what. Explanation tells us why. Theory provides the lens that transforms observation into insight.


3. From Opinion to Evidence
Old Mindset: ‚ÄúI think violent video games are harmful because they feel aggressive to me.‚Äù
New Mindset: ‚ÄúI hypothesize violent video games increase aggression. Let me design an experiment to test this claim against competing explanations.‚Äù
Opinions are starting points. Evidence is the destination. Research is the journey between them.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
1.8 Assignment: Establish Your Research Identity

The Task
Create your public GitHub Profile. You must:

Upload a professional profile picture
Add a README.md file that introduces yourself to the class and the world
Include the following sections:

Who I am: Name, pronouns, year, major
What I‚Äôm learning: Your goals for this course
What I bring: Your creative/technical background
What I‚Äôm curious about: A media phenomenon you‚Äôd like to research




Pedagogical Rationale: Why GitHub?
Why not Blackboard or a Word doc?
In a constructivist learning environment, where you build determines who you become. GitHub is the industry standard for:

Software engineers
Data scientists
Open-source researchers
Digital humanists
Computational social scientists

By establishing your presence here, you are signaling‚Äîto yourself and future employers‚Äîthat you are entering a technical domain.
The bio you write in your README.md is your first act of professional storytelling. You are no longer just a student; you are a researcher claiming your digital office.


What This Signals
When a future employer or graduate program Googles your name and finds your GitHub profile, they see:

Technical literacy: You‚Äôre comfortable in developer spaces
Public scholarship: You‚Äôre willing to work in the open
Professional identity: You‚Äôre building your career intentionally
Version control: You understand how modern knowledge work happens

This is not busywork. This is infrastructure for your future.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
Key Takeaways






TipRemember




The brain is a story processor ‚Äî We use narratives to understand reality
Research follows narrative structure ‚Äî Problem ‚Üí Investigation ‚Üí Discovery ‚Üí Meaning
The Null Hypothesis is the Sacred Flaw ‚Äî Science exposes false beliefs about the world
Journalism + Data Science = Power ‚Äî Combine depth and breadth for maximum impact
You are the protagonist ‚Äî Research transforms both your knowledge and your identity

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:

Storr, W. (2019). The Science of Storytelling. Abrams Press.
Katz, E., Blumler, J. G., & Gurevitch, M. (1974). Uses and gratifications research. Public Opinion Quarterly, 37(4), 509-523.
Leith, A. P., & Gheen, M. (2022). Parasocial relationships and streaming: Platform affordances and user motivations during COVID-19. Journal of Broadcasting & Electronic Media.

title: Chapter 1: The Science of Storytelling
text:
Discussion Questions

Think of a moment when your ‚Äúmodel of the world‚Äù was disrupted (an Inciting Incident). How did you construct a narrative to explain it?
Identify a media trend you‚Äôve noticed anecdotally. How would you transform that observation into a research question?
What‚Äôs a ‚ÄúSacred Flaw‚Äù (Null Hypothesis) you hold about social media, gaming, or digital culture? How could you test whether it‚Äôs actually true?

title: GitHub Deployment Instructions
text:
Go to https://github.com/SIM-Lab-SIUE
Click the ‚ÄúNew‚Äù button (or go to https://github.com/organizations/SIM-Lab-SIUE/repositories/new)
Fill in the repository details:

Repository name: mc451-liaison-program (or your preferred name)
Description: Liaison Program course website with Obsidian vault for students
Visibility: Choose Public (so GitHub Pages works for free)
DO NOT initialize with README, .gitignore, or license (we already have these)

Click ‚ÄúCreate repository‚Äù




Once you create the repository, GitHub will show you commands. Use these:
git remote add origin https://github.com/SIM-Lab-SIUE/mc451-liaison-program.git
git push -u origin main
OR run this command in your terminal:
cd C:\mc451-sp26\quarto_website
git remote add origin https://github.com/SIM-Lab-SIUE/mc451-liaison-program.git
git push -u origin main



After pushing:

Go to your repository on GitHub
Click Settings ‚Üí Pages (in the left sidebar)
Under ‚ÄúBuild and deployment‚Äù:

Source: Deploy from a branch
Branch: main
Folder: /_site

Click Save

GitHub will build your site. Wait 2-3 minutes, then your site will be live at:
https://sim-lab-siue.github.io/mc451-liaison-program/



Copy your GitHub Pages URL and post it in Blackboard:
üìö Course Website
Access all Liaison Program materials here:
https://sim-lab-siue.github.io/mc451-liaison-program/

You'll find:
‚úì Getting started guide
‚úì Liaison Obsidian Vault download
‚úì All course modules and materials
‚úì Weekly templates and resources

Start with the "Get Started" page!



Whenever you make changes:
cd C:\mc451-sp26\quarto_website
quarto render
git add .
git commit -m "Update course materials"
git push
GitHub Pages will automatically rebuild in 2-3 minutes.




If mc451-liaison-program is taken, try: - liaison-program-website - mc451-sp26 - communication-liaison-course - liaison-research-methods




Q: GitHub Pages shows 404 - Make sure you selected /_site folder (not root) - Wait 3-5 minutes for the first build - Check Settings ‚Üí Pages for build status
Q: Push failed - authentication error - You may need to set up a Personal Access Token - Go to GitHub Settings ‚Üí Developer settings ‚Üí Personal access tokens - Create token with repo scope - Use token as password when pushing
Q: Resource files (Liaison_Vault.zip) not showing - The .gitignore should NOT exclude resources/ - Check that resources/Liaison_Vault.zip was committed - Run: git ls-files resources/ to verify

Ready to go! Create the repository on GitHub, then run the push commands above. üöÄ

title: About Dr.¬†Leith
text:
Associate Professor & Director, SIM Lab
Department of Mass Communications
Southern Illinois University Edwardsville

title: About Dr.¬†Leith
text:
Associate Professor & Director, SIM Lab
Department of Mass Communications
Southern Illinois University Edwardsville

title: About Dr.¬†Leith
text:
Background
I‚Äôm an Associate Professor of Mass Communications at SIUE, where I direct the Social Interaction & Media Lab (SIM Lab). My research focuses on how people communicate, connect, and collaborate through digital platforms‚Äîfrom video games and streaming to virtual reality and remote work environments.
Before joining SIUE, I completed my PhD in Information and Media at Michigan State University, where I studied gameplay livestreaming and how audiences build relationships with streamers. My master‚Äôs degree in Speech Communication from SIUE examined parasocial relationships on social media platforms like Facebook.

title: About Dr.¬†Leith
text:
Research Interests
My current work explores:

Virtual Communication: How people interact, experience fatigue, and find authentic connection in virtual meetings and VR spaces
Gaming & Media: The psychology of gameplay, streaming, and how games shape communication and identity
Remote Work & Education: Supporting wellbeing and equity in virtual classrooms and distributed teams
Data & Communication: Using computational methods to understand media consumption and online behavior

title: About Dr.¬†Leith
text:
Teaching Philosophy
I believe the best research methods courses empower students to ask good questions before worrying about technical answers. This course is structured around the idea that you‚Äôre a Communication Liaison‚Äîsomeone who bridges data science and creative thinking.
I‚Äôm committed to: - Making research methods accessible (not just for math people) - Using real data and meaningful projects - Supporting diverse learning styles and backgrounds - Building a collaborative, judgment-free classroom

title: About Dr.¬†Leith
text:
Current Projects
SIM Lab focuses on: - Improving equity and wellbeing in virtual classrooms - Understanding play and professionalism in remote environments
- Designing AI-enhanced tools for better virtual interaction - Building open-source resources for communication research
You can find more at: - Web: apleith.github.io - GitHub: github.com/apleith - ORCID: 0000-0003-1310-6763

title: About Dr.¬†Leith
text:
Connect
Email: aleith@siue.edu
Office Hours: MW 10:00-11:30 AM and 1:30-3:00 PM (or by appointment)
Feel free to stop by or email questions about the course, research methods, media and communication, or anything else on your mind!

text:
What You Have
‚úÖ Quarto Website - A fully functional, professional resource site

title: Deployment Guide
text:
Deployment Options

Option 1: GitHub Pages (Recommended - FREE)

Create a GitHub repository

Go to github.com and create a new public repo named quarto_website

Push your site
cd C:\mc451-sp26\quarto_website
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit: Liaison Program website"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/quarto_website.git
git push -u origin main
Enable GitHub Pages

Go to your repo Settings ‚Üí Pages
Set Source to ‚ÄúDeploy from a branch‚Äù
Set Branch to main and folder to _site
Your site will be live at: https://YOUR_USERNAME.github.io/quarto_website

Share the link in Blackboard

Copy the GitHub Pages URL
Add it to your Blackboard course as a web link or announcement




Option 2: Netlify (FREE, Easier Setup)

Go to netlify.com and sign up
Click ‚ÄúNew site from Git‚Äù and connect your GitHub repo
Set Build Command to: quarto render
Set Publish Directory to: _site
Deploy automatically on every push



Option 3: University Server/Portal
Contact your IT department about hosting the _site/ folder on your institution‚Äôs server.

title: Welcome to the Data Team
text:
Welcome! As a Communication Liaison, you are the vital bridge between our data scientists and creative teams. Your role is to:

Translate complex data concepts into clear, actionable insights
Facilitate collaboration between technical and creative professionals
Document findings and processes for team understanding
Guide projects from discovery through delivery

This program is designed to equip you with the research methodologies, tools, and frameworks you need to excel in this unique position. Over five phases, you‚Äôll develop the skills to navigate data-driven projects while maintaining clear communication across all stakeholders.

title: Welcome to the Data Team
text:
The Five Phases
This program is structured in five interconnected phases:

Phase 1: Orientation - Understand your role, the program structure, and set up your workspace
Phase 2: Discovery - Learn research methodologies and how to ask the right questions
Phase 3: The Dictionary - Master codebook creation and variable definition
Phase 4: Execution - Apply what you‚Äôve learned to real projects
Phase 5: Delivery - Present findings and communicate impact

Each phase builds on the previous one. Start with Phase 1 in the sidebar.

title: Weekly Journal Entry Guide
text:
Each week, you‚Äôll reflect on course material using one of three approaches. Pick the one that connects most to what you‚Äôre thinking about this week.






Definition: Link this week‚Äôs material to something bigger‚Äîyour project, a previous concept, real-world examples, or your own experience.
Example Prompt: ‚ÄúHow does this week‚Äôs reading connect to what I‚Äôm working on?‚Äù




Definition: Document a challenge you faced and how you worked through it‚Äîtechnical, conceptual, or practical.
Example Prompt: ‚ÄúWhat was difficult this week, and how did I solve it?‚Äù




Definition: Ask a critical question about the material. Challenge an assumption, identify a gap, or explore an implication.
Example Prompt: ‚ÄúWhat question or assumption from this week intrigues or concerns me?‚Äù






Length: 250-300 words
Due: Every Friday by 11:59 PM
Choose ONE approach and delete the other two
Tag: Include #journal #weekX at the bottom

Your job is to translate, facilitate, and document.

Required

title: Resources & Downloads
text:
Documentation & Guides

Quick Start

Setting up your Obsidian Vault - 5 minutes
Understanding the Liaison Program Structure - 10 minutes



Setup

Download the vault from Liaison_Vault.zip and extract it.
Install Obsidian and open the extracted vault folder.
Review the course-specific setup steps in Setup Guide to connect your workspace and enable recommended plugins.
Confirm your vault sync/backup preference (local, cloud, or git) before adding content.



Program Structure

The program runs through five phases: Orientation, Discovery, Dictionary, Execution, and Delivery.
Each phase has a dedicated module page (see the sidebar) with objectives, tasks, and turn-in expectations.
Start with Phase 1: Orientation to configure your tools and complete the initial journal entry.
The START_HERE page gives a bird‚Äôs-eye view plus links to key checklists and timelines.



Templates Available in Your Vault

Weekly Journal Template - For reflective practice with three thinking paths
Data Dictionary Template - For codebook creation and variable definition

title: Resources & Downloads
text:

Questions about the program? Check your module‚Äôs orientation page
Technical issues? Review the Software & Tools section above
Need to provide feedback? Use the Inbox in your Obsidian Vault
